facts.text: Kothandarama Ayyar, Hindu inhabitant of Tanjore District, owned considerable properties and died on 25th April 1905, leaving adoptive mother Valu Ammal, widow Parbati, daughters Nagammal (widow with infant daughter Alamelu) and Gnanambal.
Kothandarama executed last will on 13th March 1905, genuineness not disputed, giving widow authority to adopt son of Gnanambal before January 1908 or son of nephews.
Widow Parbati adopted Raju Ayyar, son of testator's nephew, in terms of the will.

Raju Ayyar filed Original Suit No. 34 of 1943 in Subordinate Judge of Mayuram for recovery of possession of Kothangudi properties, alleging life interest to Nagammal under will, no disposition of remainder, vesting in him as adopted son and heir.
Gnanambal (defendant No.1) resisted claim, alleging no intestacy, entitled to properties absolutely after Nagammal's death subject to payment of Rs. 5,000 to Alamelu.
Alamelu (defendant No.2) died during trial, her heirs impleaded as defendants 3 to 9.
Subordinate Judge accepted defendant No.1 contention, dismissed plaintiff's suit.
Division Bench of Madras High Court by judgment dated November 27, 1945, reversed Subordinate Judge, allowed plaintiff's claim.
Defendant No.1 (Gnanambal) appealed to Supreme Court.
Nagammal enjoyed Injigudi house for life as per evidence.

legal_issues.text: Construction of the will regarding Kothangudi properties: whether paragraph 5 applies (Nagammal life interest, then to Gnanambal and children on payment of Rs. 5,000 to Alamelu) or only paragraph 13 (Nagammal life interest with no further disposition, leading to intestacy).
Whether paragraph 5 operative only if Gnanambal's son adopted, or applicable across contingencies including adoption of nephew's son.

petitioner_arguments.text: Plaintiff Raju Ayyar claims under paragraph 13 of will, which contains entire disposition for Kothangudi: life interest to Nagammal, no disposition of remainder, vesting in him as heir.

High Court held paragraph 5 not operative as nephew's son adopted, not Gnanambal's son; paragraph 13 exclusive, no incorporation of paragraph 5 remainder; difficulty as paragraph 13 omits Injigudi house.

respondent_arguments.text: Defendant Gnanambal entitled under paragraph 5: Kothangudi and Injigudi to Nagammal for life, then to Gnanambal and children on payment of Rs. 5,000 to Alamelu; no intestacy.

court_reasoning.text: Cardinal maxim: ascertain testator's intentions from language of will read as whole, considering surrounding circumstances; court puts itself in testator's armchair but no conjecture.
court_reasoning.key_observation: General principles of will construction settled.

court_reasoning.text: No presumption against intestacy unless ambiguity; cannot distort plain words to avoid intestacy.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Presumption not based on English necessity for Indian court.

court_reasoning.text: Will carefully prepared for contingencies: adoption of Gnanambal's son (paras 4-8), nephew's son (paras 11-16 modifications), no adoption (para 20-21). Provisions for daughters, wife, mother in paras 5-7 applicable across all contingencies.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Scheme not self-contained exclusive sets; paras 5,6,7 operative regardless.

court_reasoning.text: Paragraph 13 affirms paragraph 5 for Nagammal's enjoyment of Kothangudi; no change to paragraph 5; superfluous affirmation does not exclude remainder.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Entire paragraph 5 applies; omission of Alamelu payment likely inadvertence.

court_reasoning.text: Testator's care in disposing all properties; provisions for daughters immediate, not contingent on specific adoption.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No addition to will; interpretation applies existing provision.

holdings.text: Paragraph 5 of will applies even when nephew's son adopted: Kothangudi to Nagammal for life, remainder to Gnanambal and children subject to Rs. 5,000 to Alamelu.
Provisions in paragraphs 5,6,7 for mother, wife, daughters take effect immediately across adoption contingencies.

precedents_cited.relevance: Courts consider surrounding circumstances in construing will; no presumption against intestacy as English necessity.
Cannot distort plain words to avoid intestacy.

outcome.summary: Appeal allowed; judgment and decree of Madras High Court set aside; judgment of Subordinate Judge of Mayuram restored.
outcome.relief_granted: Defendant No.1 (Gnanambal) entitled to Kothangudi properties after Nagammal's death subject to payment of Rs. 5,000 to Alamelu.

key_quotes.text: The cardinal maxim to be observed by courts in construing a will is to endeavour to ascertain the intentions of the testator. This intention has to be gathered primarily from the language of the document which is to be read as a whole...
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: States primary principle of will construction.

key_quotes.text: Paragraph 5, which is material for our present purposes runs as follows - The whole village of Kothangudi and the house at Injigudi... shall enjoy with life interest and after her the said property shall pass to my daughter Gnanambal and her children on payment by the latter of Rs. 5,000 to Alamelu...
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Key disposition in will for Kothangudi properties.

key_quotes.text: It is not the intention of the testator that on the happening of the second contingency, all the earlier provisions of the will would stand cancelled...
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Rejects High Court's view; holds paras 5-7 applicable across contingencies.
